item.title: Manifestation contained
item.description: During the “golden week” on May 1st (Labor Day), the city center of Macao was flooded by a crowd, however, the environment was contradictory and the Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) continue to fight for survival. In the first quarter of 2025 the global unemployment rate (1.9 percent) and the unemployment rate of the residents (2.5 percent) increased 0.2 percentage points, compared to the indicators of the fourth quarter of 2024. These numbers indicate that Macau's labor market is impacting economic recession and the influx of foreign workers. The numerous stores that closed in residential areas clearly reflect economic desolation. Although the “large award for consumption in community zones 2025” seems to function as a temporary accelerator, it does not attack the root of the problem. There is social discontent in relation to the administration of the Government of MSAR, however, on May 1st, except for the situation of a citizen who was taken by the police to be investigated in the prosecutor for protesting without warning the direction of services to the Labor Affairs (DSAL), there were no manifestations or protests. As the public complaints accumulate, the social atmosphere has become visibly silent. And is that good or bad? The media revealed that the “Power of the People” group had notified the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) of its intention to organize a protest manifestation on May 1, according to the provisions of the “Law of Meeting and Manifestation” Law. Police officers “express their concern repeatedly, promoting several meetings with group members to analyze the situation and take the necessary measures” as well as “warning them of the various possibilities in the face of“ uncontrollable situations ”that would lead them to take on“ joint and and several liability ”or, otherwise, risk the“ law relating to the defense of the state's security ”. They felt the weight of the invisible pressure and reluctantly chose to present a letter where they exposed their views to DSal. An article from another newspaper praised CPSP for the way he dealt with this case. He claimed that CPSP had significantly perfected its ability to disable “the Protest planned for May 1st”, and believed that CPSP, which supervises protests and manifestations according to the law, had adopted an approach to “pros and cons” to neutralize a mildly inflamed protest, eliminating possible social disturbances that came. On the one hand, the CPSP totally respected the rights of residents to protest and to express themselves and did not explicitly reject the notification presented by the group “Power of the People”. On the other hand, CPSP used persuasion to convince the group to cancel the “May 1 protest”. Some people become condescending and think that the city gets more peaceful without protests or manifestations, and this thought is the one that worries me the most. Someone with a minimum of common sense will understand that the accumulation of social discontent is not a motivating force, but a destructive force. The promulgation of the “Right of Meeting and Manifestation Law” has been intended to safeguard residents' freedom to manifest and protest, as guaranteed by the Macao Basic Law, not to ban them. In the past, the Government of MSAR effectively communicated with the protest and demonstrations organizers and coordinated these events very well. Unfortunately, in recent years, authorities have been very nervous or guided by their own priorities; and often excite the subjects and rush to us to the level of national security. If a slight cough is condemned to cause a highly contagious and fatal virus, a lot of labor is wasted and many resources, and the vitality of society is suffocated! A forest without any sound is terrifying and a silent river is full of murderous omens. A society cannot survive without any noise.

item.title: History | Launched Chinese edition of the book by Manuel V. Basilio
item.description:
It's called “Stories and Memories-Baixo do Monte and surroundings”, it is a book by Manuel V. Basilio and its edition in Chinese will be released on May 19 at the headquarters of the Macao Retired, Retired and Pensioners Association (Apomac). The work, presented in 2023, now wins a new version and has a preface by Lok Po, director of the newspaper or Mun
It will be released next Monday, 19, the Chinese edition of another book by Manuel V. Basil, a retired teacher who has been dedicated to various investigations into the history of Macau. This time, this is the book “Stories and Memories-Baixo do Mount and surroundings”, already presented in its Portuguese version in 2023, and now has preface by Lok Po, director of the newspaper or Mun. The launch runs at the headquarters of Apomac - Macao's Retired, Retired and Pensioners Association. According to a statement from Apomac, since the first launch of the work that “several people encouraged the author to also edit a Chinese language version, given the interest that may be with the Chinese community in the dissemination of one of the most striking periods in the history of Macao - the integration of the Chinese population in the so -called 'Christian city'”, when the effective miscegenation of western and eastern crops created the barrier created by the old wall and doors of the city, all living in harmony as neighbors ”. We were in the mid -nineteenth century. More specifically, from 1844, the Portuguese administration "authorized all foreigners to buy or build houses and have any terrain in Macao." Thus, "this measure eventually favored years later, the Chinese traders who had some wealth and came to Macao from southern China to escape the Taiping rebellion, also known as the Taiping Civil War, which lasted from 1850 to 1864, having settled here and restarts their activities as entrepreneurs."
According to the same note, the end of the separation between the so -called Christian city and the zone in which the Chinese community lived was thanks “to the end of the coexistence of two jurisdictions in the Macao Peninsula - the Portuguese and the Chinese, respectively, inside and outside the city's wall that, over centuries, separated the two communities”. It was also fundamental for this new phase “the beginning of the so -called colonial period, in which the Portuguese government had territorial autonomy throughout the peninsula to the door door, which later became known as the siege door”. Election zones Where did the Chinese were installed when the end of this separation between communities and modes of life? The book describes that "one of the zones preferred by the Chinese traders to reside was precisely the one that was then called Baixa do Monte, because it is near the heart of the city." "Since then some names of public roads have changed by the desire of their residents. Do you know, by chance, the old name of Travessa dos Anjos? And the reasons why it was changed, and what was the old method used to give names to public roads? Did you know that some Chinese were also awarded with honorific titles by the Portuguese court, and that these titles had an expiration date for one or two lives?" in the note. To all these curiosities and historical facts the book of Manuel V. Basilio intends to respond. In the case of Baixa do Monte, and according to the information available in the “register of public roads and other places of the city of Macau, 1957, it was a designation for“ the southern hill slope and covering an entire area, vaguely defined, ranging from Fortaleza to the nearby streets of Palha, S. Domingos and Pedro Nolasco da Silva, between Rua de S. Paulo and Calçada do Monte ”. This was an area “where many Portuguese and macanese families lived”, and to prove this fact, Manuel V. Basil “collected data on several families, especially macanese, who resided in that city from the mid -nineteenth century to the second half of the twentieth century, and whose collection includes, namely, Baptist, Baptist, Valoma, Marques, Xavier families includes families. Crestejo, medicines, Lopes, Morais, Nogueira, Simões, Cameirão, Costa, Silva, Fernandes, Souza, Pires, Gonçalves, Jorge, Eusébio, Placé, Osório, Santos, Rosario and Martins ”. From 1963, there are families who lived in blocks 3 and 4 of “Kwok Wá Tai Há”, ie “Capitol neighborhood”, next to the sidewalk of truths, and “formed, for decades, an authentic community neighborhood of Macanese”. Currently "just a few macanese reside there." Biographies and titles But not only of streets speaks this book. The author also wrote summarized biographies of some individuals and Chinese traders who lived in downtown Mount, namely Chou Iau and Fong Seng, who, in 1880, were awarded the title of Knight by the honorary mercy of King D. Luís I of Portugal, due to the valuable contributions they made to Macau's economic and social life. The author also makes a brief description of Divinity on Tcha, the temple dedicated to him, along with the sidewalk of truths, as well as the festivities in his honor that are held annually on the 18th day of the fifth month of the lunar calendar. It also makes a brief summary of the history of some buildings that existed and others that still exist, located in the boundary zone of Baixa do Monte, including the Capitol Theater building, since its inauguration, on April 18, 1931 until its closing, on August 1, 1987, and its later requalification, which became the “Capitol Theater Shopping Center”. Thus, “Stories and Memories - Baixa do Mount and surroundings” includes “Memories, Experiences, Uses and Customs, as well as stories based on the history of Macao”, as well as valuable information about the toponymy of some Macao zones and their history.

item.title: Venice receives “Parallel Worlds”, from Macao, at the Architecture Biennial
item.description: It was inaugurated last Thursday, in Venice, at the 19th Biennial of Architecture, the show “Parallels”, which represents Macao at the Biennial and which is a project carried out by photographer Iwan Baan with architectural students at the University of St. Joseph (USJ). The curatorship is still with Wang Shu, the last Pritzker award, and Lu Wenyu. This is a show that reveals the coexistence of “parallel worlds” in Macao, combining “Macao urban landscape images captured by the famous humanistic architecture photographer Iwan Baan and facilities created by teachers and students from the Faculty of Architecture of the China Academy of Arts and the Faculty of Architecture and Design at the University of São José de Macao”. Thus, it is represented “the urban fabric of the city where Chinese and Western cultures, old and new styles have coexisting for over 400 years,” says a note from the Cultural Institute (IC). There are, in this show, four “parallel worlds”, namely “the deep space of the historic city, the hotel architecture that embodies the merger between East and West, the geometric order of the modern city, representing its vibrant development; and the future projection of a digitized and intangible city, which defines an innovative view for Macau”. Reveal the heritage According to the IC, "through aerial photography and a unique perspective, Iwan Baan demonstrated the relationship between architecture, urban landscape and the natural environment of Macau, being highly engaging and narrative." "Young people from the colleges of architecture in the interior of China and Macao brought to the exhibition several creative facilities that provide ideas for the future development of Macao's urban architecture." Leong Wai Man, president of the IC, said in his speech in Venice that "world cultural heritage focused on the historic center of Macau and the modern buildings around the city show the harmony between the past and the present, constituting a vivid representation of the integration of Chinese and Western cultures," this exposure in Venice "reflects exactly the precious cultural content of Macau." The exhibition “Parallel Worlds” can be seen until November 23 this year at Arsenale, Campo Della Tana, Castello 2126/A, 30122, in Venice.

item.title: Rui Cunha Foundation hosts “polyphony” until next week
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) hosts until Saturday next week, the 17th, the collective exhibition “Polithonia”, with works by artist Gu Yue and six doctoral students from the Faculty of Humanities and Arts of the University of Science and Technology of Macao (Must), co-organizer of the event. The project makes known 20 works that represent the forms and styles of renowned artist and professor Gu Yue and his disciples Luo Su, Zhu Zhaohui, Wang Kongbin, Ding Song, Guo Weiwei, and Wei Dongsheng. According to a FRC note, this exhibition presents “a visual banquet that transcends tradition and contemporaneity, the material and digital, the place and the global, through the collision of various media and the resonance of ideas”. The works include various art forms, “such as installations, oil paintings, lacquer paintings, sand paintings and details to detail brush, displaying Macau's unique artistic ecosystem as a cultural convergence point”, is referred to. The name of the exhibition originates “in musical terminology, referring to the opposition and symbiosis of multiple voices”. The presentation of the show states that "the mission of art is to create cognitive disorientation", and "through the confrontation between traditional crafts and the new media, and the rapport of local cultural genes and global issues, it breaks the linear narrative and invites the audience to calibrate their cognition in the" glow between brightness and residual shadow. " Joint work Professor Gu Yue aligns his work and the investigation with the main theme of the exhibition. The creations of the six doctoral students "start from individual experiences and respond to propositions such as identity, time and memory in the age of digital capital, also forming a multi-wing resonance of thought." Exhibition is not only a concentrated exhibition of academic achievements, but also a speculative experience on the essence of art. “In this culturally stratified place of Macao, polyphony tries to use art as a prism to reflect the symbiotic possibilities of multiple realities,” describes the team, cited by the same note.

item.title: Macau maintains shipping by air to the United States
item.description: The Macau Post Office Director told Lusa yesterday that, unlike neighboring Hong Kong, the region kept ordering orders to the United States (USA), but only by air. On May 2, the US government eliminated the exemption of customs rights on small orders from mainland China and Hong Kong, such as those sent by the giants of Electronic Trade Shein and Temu. "In practice, now Macau is not included and the mail [which] goes to the United States is walking, except maritime. The rest, we keep normal," said Derby Lau Wai Meng. The Director of Post and Telecommunications Services (CTT) explained that the shipping of any goods, from sea to the US, implies a passage through Hong Kong, one of the busiest ports in the world. That is, there is only the hypothesis of sending orders by air, confirmed Derby Lau. "This case is sensitive," admitted the leader. "I think it's better not to talk [this subject], because the best thing is not to remember us," he added. Trump in Action The end of the exemption of customs rights on small orders from mainland China and Hong Kong emerged in an executive order, signed by US President Donald Trump on April 2. The document asked the US Secretary of Commerce, Howard Lutnick, to submit a report, within 90 days, if the end of the exemption should also cover Macao, "to avoid escape to these measures." On April 16, Hong Kong's post office announced the suspension of sending orders to the United States in response to the imposition, "abusive", tariffs by US authorities. A presidential decree issued by Donald Trump, still in the first term, in 2020, eliminated the preferential treatment granted to Hong Kong. The ancient British colony is therefore also affected by the 145 percent surcharge imposed on China. Chinese Communist Party's main official for Hong Kong and Macao affairs and governments of both regions accused the United States of imposing tariffs in mid -April to sabotage China. Macao Executive leader Sam Hou Fai criticized the United States for the “abusive imposition of customs taxes on all his business partners,” including China, “under various pretexts”. Yesterday, the US representative for the United States, Jamieson Greer, said Washington and Beijing will suspend the majority of customs rights and negotiate for 90 days. In the negotiations made in Geneva, the United States and China agreed to reduce the reciprocal customs rights imposed on each other, passing Chinese imports to pay a 30 percent customs right, while US products will pay a 10 percent customs right.

item.title: Church | Stability in local Christian communities
item.description:
Robert Francis Prevost was chosen for days as the new leader of the Catholic Church, having adopted the name of Leo XIV. HM has heard two analysts on any impacts on the functioning of dioceses in Macau and Hong Kong and what is expected is continuity and stability, such as a peaceful relationship with Beijing
Only two days lasted the choice of a new Pope after Francis' death. Leo XIV, born Robert Francisc Prevost in Chicago, USA, was the choice of Vatican's conclave cardinals. HM spoke to two analysts to try to understand any impacts or changes in the functioning of the Catholic Church on the dioceses of Macau and Hong Kong, but the course seems to be that of stability. “I don't think there will be anything concrete. The situation in Hong Kong and Macau is quite well understood and stable. I know that Catholics and people of good will in both places will be praying and wishing Pope Lion all graces, blessings and successes in their pontificate,” said Stephen Morgan, Rector of the University of St. Joseph (USJ). Already Peter Stilwell, who preceded Morgan in the rectory of USJ and is currently director of the Department of Ecumenical Relations and Interreligious Dialogue of Patriarchate of Lisbon, argues that "the relationship of Hong Kong and Macao with mainland China [regarding religion] is determined by the 90s agreements." “What will happen, at the end of the 50 years planned for the transition, will depend on many variables in a world and in a country (China) in very quick transformation. However, the Holy See has established with both dioceses [from Macau and Hong Kong] a relationship that maintains them outside any episcopal conference and in a direct relationship with Rome. To answer 'no'. However, the evolution of the agreement as Beijing, about the appointment of the Catholic bishops to the dioceses of mainland China, will be an important factor to observe, ”noted Peter Stilwell. He also added that "those interested in this evolution, however, will be closely observed how Pope Leo XIV Restructure, or not, the Vatican Secretariat of State - namely, the team that directly accompanies the Dossier of China." Ancient relationship Asked about the Vatican State relationship with Beijing with Leo XIV in power, the former USJ rector also does not foresee major changes. "The relationship will continue, discreet, but persistent, as so far. Contact has a 400 -year story, and we should not reduce it to the recent agreement on bishops." It is an agreement that "takes place between two entities with millennial memory, which think in terms of decades and centuries." "The fact that the new Pope is US nationality will be irrelevant. As head of state, his nationality has now become the Vatican City; and the daily interpeairs he will respond will have the prospect of a religious community that today extends to virtually every country in the world," said Peter Stilwell. Stephen Morgan believes that Roberto Prevost's choice for Pope has nothing to do with Trump's presence at the White House or political moves in the face of the China-Use relationship. "His election will have more to do with the fact that he is familiar with the situation of Catholics in the developing world and having had a few years of experience in Roman Courier, where he has established himself as a pair of safe hands he thinks for himself and hears broadly." Robert Prevost was brought to the Vatican by Pope Francis in 2023 to be responsible for examining the nominations of bishops around the world, one of the most important works of the Catholic Church, thus gaining prominence in the conclave.

item.title: Tourism | Andy Wu says concerts are not enough to attract visitors
item.description:
The government says it wants to bet on the organization of large -scale shows to streamline the economy in neighborhoods with less tourism, but Andy Wu, a tourism -related associative leader, says that this is not enough, defending the sale of tickets with associated discounts to take more people to consume in the territory
It is not music for the ears of tourism. Na visão de Andy Wu, presidente da Associação da Indústria Turística de Macau, não basta a realização de grandes espectáculos em Macau, nomeadamente concertos, para aumentar o número de consumidores nos bairros comunitários, ou seja, que estão mais afastados dos pontos turísticos. According to the newspaper or Mun, Andy Wu argued that complementary measures are needed to perform the concerts, namely the sale of tickets combined with associated discounts in local stores, so that people who go to the concert can also consume before the shows. Regarding the night economy, in bars and nightclubs, Andy Wu has stated that it still cannot be attractive enough for tourists, so it is important to have complementary measures to concerts. The government said that it is negotiating with ticket sales platforms a partnership to have ticket packages with discounts in stores, which should be a reality in the second half of the year, following many visitors from the interior of China to watch concerts or sports competitions in Macao. Regarding the discount model to adopt, Andy Wu argued that one can take into account the format of the consumer award for the currently underway community zones, which would allow visitors to use coupons in local commerce. This would be more suitable than leading tourists to consume only in stores adhering to the discount program, he said. Be effective Given the negotiations carried out by the executive, Andy Wu referred to the newspaper to expect these partnerships to be launched in due time, namely in June, when the second large concert was held at Cotai, in the outdoor shows, near the Grand Lisbon Palace venture. Andy Wu has not yet forgotten public transport factor, essential for tourists to have better access to community neighborhoods before and after the shows. The suggestion of experimental creation of exclusive buses, of the genus Shuttle-Bus, was made, with concrete paths between the shows zone and the community neighborhoods, so that visitors move to less known neighborhoods in Macau during the day and see the show at night.
